column5: Sport and Media: Discussion	37	I appreciate Deputy Fitzpatrick's questions. There is strong bilateral engagement between the Department and the Northern Ireland equivalent and its officials. column7: if one considers sport as a space for peace building in communities in the North. One thing we intend to do through the shared island unit in the Department of the Taoiseach is to have that conversation on advancing co-operation on sport and to use that unit to advance the use of sport as a pillar to build peace. column9: for example
column10: on allowing young people to return to training next week. The Government decided that. I recognise the difficulty the suspension of sport has caused for so many people over the last number of months
column11: but we are ambitious to prioritise that in the Government decision next week.

column8: indeed

column12: which is part of the discussion on major events

column14: a closed shop
column15: and excess capitalism. The Taoiseach has sent a very strong message
column16: along with other European leaders. I will be sending a very strong message with other sports ministers across Europe. We will also be supporting UEFA and the whole principle of UEFA

column18: and all young people across the world where football is about participation and community. It is not about this type of excessive capitalism that we have seen in recent days. column20: that we need to ensure football is grassroots based

column25: and I have demonstrated that in recent weeks. The European Super League proposal is everything that sport should reject. I am completely opposed to it and will work with all colleagues to send a strong message from an Irish perspective.
